toxins.name: Insoluble calcium oxalate crystals (often referred to as raphides)
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Mechanical Irritation: These needle-like crystals are bundled within specialized plant cells called idioblasts.
    ◦ Release upon Chewing: When a cat bites or crushes the plant tissue, these cells violently eject the sharp crystals into the soft tissues of the mouth, tongue, and throat.
    ◦ Immediate Trauma: This embedding of crystals causes immediate, intense physical pain, tissue trauma, and inflammation (edema), which can lead to swelling of the lips, tongue, and upper airway.
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Distribution: These crystals are found throughout the entire plant, including the leaves and stems.
    ◦ Severity: The toxicity is generally classified as moderate. While usually not fatal, the immediate pain typically prevents the cat from consuming a lethal amount, though severe swelling can occasionally compromise breathing.• Houseplants and Ornamentals Toxic to Animals - Toxicology - Merck Veterinary Manual1,2,3,4

symptoms.name: Intense burning, pain, and irritation of the mouth, tongue, and lips
symptoms.onset: Immediate (Pain occurs as soon as the plant tissue is chewed).
symptoms.notes: The plant contains insoluble calcium oxalate crystals packaged in specialized cells (idioblasts) that forcefully eject into the tissue upon biting, causing micro-trauma. You may see the cat pawing at its mouth.Hypersalivation

symptoms.name: Drooling or excessive salivation (Ptyalism)
symptoms.onset: Immediate to within minutes of ingestion.
symptoms.notes: This is a reflex response to the intense irritation and burning sensation in the oral cavity.Edema (Swelling)

symptoms.name: Swelling of the lips, tongue, and oral cavity
symptoms.notes: In rare cases, swelling can extend to the pharynx (throat) or larynx (voice box). Severe swelling of the tongue or throat can potentially compromise the airway, though this is uncommon.Dysphagia

symptoms.name: Difficulty swallowing
symptoms.notes: The cat may show an inability to eat or drink due to the pain and swelling in the mouth and throat.Gastrointestinal Upset

symptoms.name: Vomiting and anorexia (refusal to eat)
symptoms.notes: Vomiting may occur due to the irritation of the stomach lining or the gag reflex triggered by oral swelling. The cat may refuse food (anorexia) simply because it hurts to chew and swallow.Respiratory Distress (Rare)

symptoms.name: Dyspnea (Difficulty breathing)
symptoms.notes: While rare, if the swelling of the tongue or glottis is significant, it can obstruct the upper airway. This requires immediate veterinary intervention to secure an airway.

treatments.name: Airway Stabilization and Oxygen Support
treatments.description: If the cat is experiencing respiratory distress, the veterinarian will immediately provide oxygen support. In severe cases where swelling (edema) obstructs the throat, they may need to secure an airway (intubation) to ensure the cat can breathe.
treatments.notes: While rare, laryngeal edema (swelling of the voice box and upper airway) can occur due to the inflammatory reaction caused by the crystals. This is a life-threatening complication that requires immediate intervention before other treatments.

treatments.name: Oral Decontamination (Rinsing)
treatments.description: The veterinarian will physically remove any remaining plant material from the mouth and thoroughly rinse or wipe the oral cavity with cool water.
treatments.notes: The goal is to flush out the needle-like oxalate crystals causing the physical trauma. Rinsing helps reduce the immediate pain and prevents further embedding of the crystals in the soft tissues.

treatments.name: Administration of Demulcents (Calcium-Containing Products)
treatments.description: The administration of milk or other calcium-containing dairy products (like yogurt) to the cat.
treatments.notes: Insoluble oxalates bind to the calcium found in dairy products. This reaction helps precipitate the crystals, aiding in their clearance from the oral cavity and esophagus while soothing the irritated mucous membranes.

treatments.name: Symptomatic and Supportive Care (Fluids and Analgesics)
treatments.description:
◦ Fluid Therapy: Administration of subcutaneous or intravenous fluids if the cat is dehydrated or unable to drink due to mouth pain.
    ◦ Medications: Analgesics (pain relievers) and anti-inflammatories to manage oral swelling and discomfort. Gastroprotectants may be used if the stomach is irritated.
treatments.notes: Most cases of Chinese Evergreen ingestion are self-limiting and have a good to excellent prognosis. Veterinary intervention is primarily needed to manage pain and hydration until the swelling subsides and the cat can eat and drink normally again.
